sections.title: Dentistry with calm precision
sections.label: Overview
sections.copy:
St Mary’s House Dental Care is a long-established private practice in Shoreham-by-Sea. We focus on careful planning, calm delivery, and dentistry that makes sense for the long term.

We look after everyday oral health and also support complex cases involving tooth wear, missing teeth, implant-supported restorations, heavily restored mouths, and bite-related problems.

Appointments are structured so you understand what we’ve found, what it means, and what your realistic options are. If you’re anxious, short on time, or simply want things explained properly, we’ll take a measured approach and agree the next step together.

sections.label: Who we are
sections.title: Dentistry designed for clarity, comfort, and long-term confidence
sections.copy:
Care at St Mary’s House is built around time, explanation, and respect for every patient’s circumstances.

We provide general, restorative, implant, orthodontic, and aesthetic dentistry, but we don’t rush decisions or push treatment. Appointments are unhurried, explanations are clear, and choices are made collaboratively.

Many of our patients tell us they feel listened to here. That matters to us.

sections.title: Clinical depth with steady hands
items: Over 30 years of experience across restorative and orthodontic care.
Advanced restorative and orthodontic training applied to complex cases.
CBCT-guided implant planning for precise placement and healing.
In-house digital dentistry to shorten feedback loops and keep planning clear.
sections.label: Trusted practice detail
Clinical philosophy
sections.title: Care that values planning as much as precision
sections.copy:
Good dentistry isn’t just about a single procedure. It’s about understanding bite, function, health, aesthetics, and long-term stability — and planning accordingly.

We take a conservative, evidence-led approach. When care becomes complex or irreversible — implants, extractions, root canal treatment, veneers, larger restorative plans — we slow things down, map out options clearly, and proceed step by step with your comfort and understanding at the centre.

Complex & multidisciplinary care
sections.title: Structured care for complex situations
sections.copy:
Many patients come to us after years of piecemeal dentistry, unresolved problems, or uncertainty about what should happen next. These cases need structure, not speed.

Our approach brings disciplines together — restorative, orthodontic, implant, and digital planning — so treatment is sequenced sensibly and reviewed carefully. For missing teeth, that may include implant-supported restorations or implant-retained dentures, planned with stability, comfort, and ease of maintenance in mind.

The aim is a clearer path forward before anything irreversible begins.

sections.title: Established care for Shoreham-by-Sea and surrounding communities
sections.copy:
We’ve cared for generations of patients from Shoreham-by-Sea, Lancing, Southwick, Worthing, and Brighton. Many stay with us for years — not because they need ongoing treatment, but because they value consistency and trust.

Dentistry works high standards when your dentist knows your history, priorities, and concerns. Our aim is to provide that continuity, whether you’re visiting for routine care or planning something more involved.

faqs.question: What happens at the first visit?
faqs.answer: We listen to goals, capture scans or photos if helpful, and outline options with straightforward next steps.

faqs.question: Do you show previews before treatment?
faqs.answer: Whenever possible we use visual planning so you can see movement, shaping, or shade shifts before committing.

faqs.question: How do payments work?
faqs.answer: We share estimates early, support staged payments, and provide receipts or documentation you may need.

faqs.question: Do you help with directions or parking?
faqs.answer: Yes—call or message ahead and we will outline nearby parking options and the high standards entrance to use.

faqs.question: Can I start with a phone discussion?
faqs.answer: You can request a call-back through the contact page to discuss your goals before booking a visit.

faqs.question: Do you see patients from nearby towns?
faqs.answer: We regularly welcome patients from Shoreham-by-Sea, Lancing, Worthing, Southwick, Hove, and Brighton.

faqs.question: Is the practice suitable for nervous patients?
faqs.answer: Yes—gentle pacing, clear numbing options, and calm explanations are part of every visit.

sections.label: Patient journey
sections.title: A clear, supportive first step
sections.copy:
Your first visit is about listening, understanding your concerns, and gathering the information needed to guide you properly. You don’t need to know where to start. We’ll take things step by step.

Where treatment is required, options are explained clearly, including benefits, limitations, costs, and timescales. From there, you can decide how — or whether — to proceed, with support available at every stage.

implants.label: Dental Implants in Shoreham-by-Sea
implants.intro: Stable, natural-looking implant restorations with calm planning and follow-up.

sections.title: Planning first, surgery second
sections.label: Introduction
sections.copy: Dental implants replace missing teeth using a small titanium post that supports a crown, bridge, or implant-retained denture. Planning matters: before any surgery we assess your mouth, review your medical history, and use CBCT imaging and digital scans to map bone, nerves, bite and the final tooth shape. This allows us to discuss realistic options, timing, and whether additional steps such as bone grafting or sinus lift assessment may be relevant. If implants aren’t the right fit, we’ll explain alternatives such as bridges or removable solutions and help you choose an approach that’s stable, maintainable and comfortable long-term.

sections.title: A conservative route to refined change
sections.label: Introduction
sections.copy: Veneers are thin restorations placed on the front surface of teeth to refine shape, colour and alignment. They can be an excellent option when the teeth underneath are healthy enough, and when the plan is conservative and carefully staged. We start by understanding what you’d like to change, then assess enamel, bite, gum health and wear patterns so the result is stable and maintainable. In many cases, we can explore minimal-prep or additive approaches, or consider alternatives such as whitening, bonding, or aligners first. If veneers are suitable, we’ll talk through preview options, longevity factors and how to protect the finished work.

sections.title: Clear aligners with clear diagnosis
sections.label: Introduction
sections.copy: Clear aligners straighten teeth using a series of custom trays that move teeth in small, planned steps. The key is diagnosis and planning: we assess your bite, gum health, tooth wear and any jaw symptoms, then use digital scans to model movement and discuss what’s realistic. Aligners can help with crowding, spacing and some bite corrections, but not every case is suitable — and retention is essential to keep results stable. We’ll also discuss where aligners fit alongside whitening, bonding or restorative work, especially if you’re planning a broader smile refresh. If aligners are recommended, you’ll receive a clear timeline, check-in plan and aftercare guidance.

sections.title: Smile transformations, simplified
sections.copy: Our smile gallery shares examples of treatments carried out at St Mary’s House Dental Care, with the aim of helping you understand what different options can look like in real life. Every smile is unique and results vary, so these cases are here to support informed conversations — not to promise a specific outcome. Where we share before-and-after images, we do so with consent and with context about the type of work involved. If you see a result you like, we can discuss whether a similar approach is clinically suitable for you, and what the planning would involve.
sections.label: Overview

sections.title: Cases overview
sections.copy:
Each case includes a brief summary of the starting point, the type of treatment provided, and the kind of planning involved.

Where before-and-after images are shown, they are there to help you understand what may be possible — not to suggest you will get an identical result. Photographs also don’t show everything that matters in dentistry, such as bite, gum health, long-term maintenance, or the stability of the underlying teeth.

If you see a style of outcome you like, we can talk through whether a similar approach is clinically suitable for you and what would need to be assessed first.

sections.title: About St Mary’s House Dental Care
sections.copy:
St Mary’s House Dental Care is a long-established private dental practice in Shoreham-by-Sea.

We work in a calm, clinician-led way: careful assessment, clear explanation, and treatment planned for long-term stability rather than quick fixes.

If you’re nervous about dentistry, or you’ve had mixed experiences in the past, we’ll take things at a pace that feels manageable and explain what we’re doing as we go.

sections.title: An independent practice by choice
sections.copy:
How we work is simple, even if the dentistry isn’t.

We start with understanding the problem properly before talking about solutions. We explain options in plain English, including limits and trade-offs. Where it helps outcomes and costs, we plan treatment in stages. And we focus on comfort, fit, and long-term maintenance — not hype.

sections.title: A practice built on relationships
sections.copy:
The practice has been part of the Shoreham area for many years, and the building itself reflects that history.

Dentistry has changed a lot over time, but the principles haven’t: careful diagnosis, sensible planning, and work you can live with comfortably. We continue to improve how we assess, plan, and deliver care, while keeping the experience calm and straightforward.

sections.title: Part of Shoreham, not just located in it
sections.copy:
Good dentistry should feel understandable and unrushed.

Whether you need a simple check-up or more involved restorative work, our job is to help you make clear decisions you’ll still feel comfortable with in five and ten years’ time.

sections.title: Our team
sections.copy:
Dentistry works best when it’s delivered by people who know each other well.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, we’re a small, experienced team who work together every day — not a rotating cast. That continuity matters. It affects communication, planning, and how calmly care is delivered.

Patients often tell us they value recognising familiar faces and feeling understood rather than processed.
sections.label: Team

sections.title: How we work together
sections.copy:
Good outcomes in dentistry depend on more than individual skill.

They rely on clear communication between clinicians and nurses, shared standards of care, and consistency in how patients are looked after. Our team works closely across examinations, hygiene, restorative care, and longer-term treatment planning.

That collaboration reduces errors, avoids duplication, and makes appointments feel more settled.
sections.label: Trust and continuity

sections.label: Profile intro
sections.copy:
Dr Nick Maxwell
Principal Dentist · Restorative, Aesthetic & Digital Dentistry

I’m Dr Nick Maxwell, principal dentist at St Mary’s House Dental Care in Shoreham-by-Sea.
I’ve been practising dentistry since 1998 and have spent much of my career focused on the kind of dentistry that needs calm judgment: complex restorative work, aesthetic planning, bite stability, and carefully selected implant and orthodontic cases.
My aim is simple: help patients make decisions they can feel good about years from now — not just next month.

sections.label: Credentials
sections.copy:
Qualifications and training

I hold:
• BDS (King’s College London)
• MSc Restorative & Aesthetic Dentistry
• PGDip Orthodontics & Facial Orthopaedics
I’ve also completed implant surgical training and intensive implant placement training (Cairo, 2014).
Qualifications matter, but what matters most is what they change in day-to-day care: the ability to plan, select cases carefully, and avoid unnecessary intervention.

sections.label: Care philosophy
sections.copy:
How I work

Dentistry can be rushed. It can also be over-sold. I’m not interested in either.
My approach is deliberately planning-first and case-by-case:
• We start with diagnosis and stability, not “what you’d like done”
• We talk honestly about trade-offs and limitations
• I’m happy to recommend the simplest sensible option — and equally happy to advise against treatment that isn’t in your long-term interest
That’s what I mean by “sleep-at-night dentistry”.

sections.label: Additional media
sections.copy:
Digital dentistry and 3D planning

Over the past several years I’ve developed a strong focus on digital dentistry — not as a gimmick, but as a way to plan more precisely and communicate more clearly.
This includes:
• digital planning workflows for restorative and implant cases
• CBCT-based assessment where appropriate
• designing and 3D-printing surgical guides for guided implant placement
• a strong emphasis on predictability and maintainability
Technology doesn’t replace clinical judgment — but used properly, it helps reduce uncertainty and improves decision-making.

Patients often come to see me when they want a calm, honest second opinion, a long-term plan rather than a quick fix, and careful aesthetic work that still respects tooth structure. If you’re looking for rushed dentistry, I won’t be the right fit. If you want careful, clinician-led planning, you probably will.

sections.label: Profile intro
sections.copy:
Dr Sylvia Krafft is an Associate Dentist at St Mary’s House Dental Care in Shoreham-by-Sea. She qualified as a Zahnarzt (Dental Surgeon) at the University of Cologne and has over 20 years’ experience working in general dentistry across Germany, the United States and the United Kingdom.

Patients commonly see Dr Krafft for general dental care, prevention-focused treatment and aesthetic dentistry delivered with a conservative, minimally invasive approach. She has a particular interest in improving the appearance of teeth in ways that remain biologically sound and appropriate for long-term oral health.

Since relocating to the UK in 2009, Dr Krafft has worked extensively in both NHS and private practice. Her international background allows her to draw on a broad range of clinical perspectives, supporting thoughtful, individualised care for patients of all ages.

She is especially valued by patients who want careful explanations, realistic expectations and treatment that enhances confidence without unnecessary intervention.

sections.label: Credentials
sections.copy:
Dr Krafft qualified as a Zahnarzt (Dental Surgeon) at the University of Cologne (Zahnklinik Köln) in 2001. In addition to her dental qualification, she is also a trained dental technician, giving her a detailed understanding of dental materials, morphology and precision.

Early in her career, she worked in general practice in Germany before moving to the United States, where she volunteered at a dental charity hospital in Miami. This experience reinforced her commitment to ethical, patient-centred care and to providing treatment that balances clinical need with individual circumstance.

Since moving to the UK in 2009, Dr Krafft has gained over 15 years’ experience across NHS and private dentistry. She has developed a particular interest in aesthetic dentistry delivered conservatively, focusing on proportion, harmony and tooth preservation rather than aggressive cosmetic change.

Her background as both clinician and technician informs a careful, detail-led approach, especially when planning aesthetic or restorative work. GDC: 174528.

sections.label: Care philosophy
sections.copy:
Dr Krafft’s clinical approach is centred on prevention, minimal intervention and patient understanding. She believes that aesthetic dentistry should enhance natural features rather than replace them, and that successful outcomes depend on respecting the biology of teeth and gums.

She prioritises conservative solutions wherever possible and takes time to explain options clearly, including what can be achieved predictably and what may introduce unnecessary risk. Patients are encouraged to make informed decisions at a pace that feels comfortable, with realistic expectations set from the outset.

For patients who feel anxious, Dr Krafft focuses on building trust through calm communication and a supportive, unhurried approach. Treatment is adapted to individual comfort levels, and patients are kept fully informed and in control throughout their care.

Her dual training as a dentist and dental technician supports a precise, considered approach to both aesthetic and functional treatment. Long-term oral health, stability and maintainability are always prioritised over short-term cosmetic change.

sections.label: Additional media
sections.copy: Dr Krafft values dentistry for the balance it offers between technical precision and human connection. She enjoys helping patients feel more confident about their smile in a way that remains natural and sustainable, and takes particular satisfaction in supporting patients who appreciate careful, considered care rather than rushed solutions.

sections.label: Profile video placeholder
sections.title: Video spotlight
sections.copy: Reserved for the clinician intro video beneath the hero.

sections.label: Profile intro
sections.copy:
Sara Burden is a Dental Hygienist at St Mary’s House Dental Care, with over 30 years’ experience in dental hygiene. She qualified from Birmingham Dental School in 1990 and has worked across general practice, specialist care and research settings.

Patients commonly see Sara for periodontal care, maintenance appointments and support with gum health, particularly where long-term stability is essential. She is known for her gentle, thorough approach and for helping patients feel at ease, especially those who may feel anxious about hygiene treatment.

Sara plays an important role within the practice’s preventative and long-term care philosophy, working closely with the dentists to support restorative and implant treatment planning through ongoing periodontal health.

sections.label: Credentials
sections.copy:
Sara qualified as a dental hygienist from Birmingham Dental School in 1990. Over the course of her career, she has gained extensive experience in general dental practice, specialist environments and dental research.

She has a particular interest in the management of acute gum conditions and in the relationship between oral health, nutrition and systemic wellbeing. Sara takes a holistic view of periodontal care, supporting patients with practical, evidence-based advice alongside clinical treatment.

She remains committed to maintaining high professional standards and keeps her knowledge up to date through regular continuing professional development, ensuring her approach reflects current best practice in periodontal care. GDC: 3966.

sections.label: Care philosophy
sections.copy:
Sara’s approach to dental hygiene is preventative, methodical and patient-focused. She believes effective periodontal care relies on understanding, consistency and realistic guidance that patients can apply between visits.

She takes time to explain findings clearly, discuss contributing factors and demonstrate techniques where helpful, allowing patients to feel informed rather than overwhelmed. Appointments are unhurried and adapted to individual comfort levels, with particular consideration given to patients who may feel nervous or sensitive.

Sara places strong emphasis on long-term maintenance, recognising that stable gum health is essential for both natural teeth and restorative work. Her aim is to support predictable, sustainable oral health outcomes through collaborative care and clear communication.

sections.label: Additional media
sections.copy: Sara values the long-term relationships that develop through preventative care and enjoys supporting patients as their oral health improves over time. She takes particular satisfaction in helping people feel more comfortable, confident and informed about their gum health.

sections.title: Fees and planning
sections.label: Overview
sections.copy:
Dental fees vary because treatment depends on the condition of the teeth and gums, the complexity of care, and the time and materials required.

Two people having what sounds like the same treatment may need very different levels of care.

Because of this, we avoid giving fixed prices without first seeing you.

sections.title: How we approach fees
sections.copy:
Before any treatment is started, we take time to understand what you actually need. This usually involves an examination, appropriate X-rays or scans, and a discussion about your priorities.

Where treatment is straightforward, fees can often be estimated quite accurately. For more complex or staged care, we will explain the likely range and the factors that could affect it.

You will always be given a written treatment plan before going ahead, and nothing is carried out without your agreement.
sections.label: How we approach fees

sections.title: Why dentistry costs vary
sections.copy:
If you are unsure whether a particular treatment is appropriate, or simply want to understand likely costs before booking, please get in touch.

Initial conversations are about understanding your situation, not committing you to treatment.
sections.label: Why dentistry costs vary

sections.title: What our fees include
sections.copy:
Our fees are not just for the treatment you receive on the day. They reflect the full clinical process, which may include:

• detailed assessment and diagnosis
• digital imaging and planning where appropriate
• high-quality materials and laboratory work
• time for careful, unhurried delivery
• follow-up care and review

This approach supports safe, well-planned care that is tailored to you — not simply completed quickly.
sections.label: What our fees include

sections.title: Staged treatment and flexible planning
sections.copy:
Not all dental treatment needs to be done at once.

In many cases, care can be planned in stages, allowing you to prioritise what matters most and spread treatment over time. This approach often leads to better long-term outcomes and more manageable costs.

We are happy to talk through different options and help you decide what feels right for you.
sections.label: Staged treatment and flexible planning

sections.title: Finance and affordability
sections.copy:
Payment is usually taken at the time of treatment. For larger treatment plans, finance options may be available to help spread the cost.

If finance is something you would like to consider, we can explain how it works and whether it may be suitable for your situation.

We’ll always explain costs clearly before treatment starts, so you’re not faced with surprises.

sections.title: Contact St Mary’s House Dental Care
sections.copy:
Getting in touch should feel straightforward.

Whether you’d like to arrange an appointment, ask a question, or talk something through before deciding what to do next, our team will help guide you calmly and clearly.

There’s no obligation to proceed with treatment simply by contacting us. Many people get in touch because they want to understand their options, what an initial appointment involves, or whether something sounds urgent.

We’re a private dental practice based in Shoreham-by-Sea, and we see patients with a wide range of concerns — from routine check-ups to more complex dental problems.

If you feel unsure, or it’s been a while since you last saw a dentist, that’s very common. Let us know when you contact us and we can take things at a pace that feels manageable.

sections.title: How to contact us
sections.copy:
You’re welcome to contact the practice by phone or by using the enquiry form on this page.

If your question is straightforward, our reception team can usually help directly. If it’s more clinical, we’ll make sure it’s passed to the right person.

Messages are read during normal opening hours and we aim to respond as promptly as we can. Email and online enquiries aren’t suitable for urgent dental problems.

Any information provided before an appointment is general in nature and can’t replace a clinical assessment. Treatment recommendations, where appropriate, are only made after we’ve seen you and discussed your individual circumstances.

sections.title: Care downloads
sections.label: Overview
sections.copy:
The documents on this page are provided to support your care with us.

They may include aftercare guidance, treatment information, and practical notes that are useful before or after an appointment. Not every document will apply to everyone, and some information is only relevant in certain situations.

If you’ve been given a specific document by the team, you can usually find it here. If you’re unsure which information applies to you, or if something isn’t clear, we’re always happy to help explain.

Written guidance is helpful, but it can’t replace a proper conversation or clinical assessment. If something doesn’t feel right, or you have concerns following treatment, it’s important to contact the practice rather than relying only on written information.

The documents here are reviewed from time to time, so you may notice updates as guidance changes.

---

sections.title: Privacy and your information
sections.label: Overview
sections.copy:
This privacy notice explains how St Mary’s House Dental Care uses and protects personal information.

We are committed to handling personal data responsibly and in line with UK data protection law.

We may collect personal information when you contact the practice, book an appointment, complete forms, or use this website.

This can include contact details, appointment information, and technical data such as IP address and browser type when you use the site.

Personal information is used to provide dental care, manage appointments, communicate with you, and meet our legal and professional obligations.

We do not sell personal data and only share information where necessary for care, administration, or legal reasons.

We take appropriate steps to keep personal information secure, including access controls and secure systems.

Data is kept only for as long as required by clinical, legal, or regulatory obligations.

You have rights under UK data protection law, including the right to access your information and request corrections.

If you have questions about how your data is used, or wish to exercise your rights, please contact the practice.

This privacy notice may be updated from time to time to reflect changes in law or how we operate.

The current version will always be available on this website.

items.title: What information we collect
items.copy: We may collect information you provide when you contact us or book an appointment (for example, name, contact details and appointment-related information). When you use the website, it may also collect limited technical information needed for it to function properly.

items.title: Why we use it
items.copy: We use personal information to manage appointments, respond to enquiries, provide dental care where appropriate, and meet legal and professional obligations.

items.title: Who we share it with
items.copy: We do not sell personal data. We only share information when it’s necessary for care, administration, or legal reasons, and we aim to share the minimum needed.

items.title: How long we keep it
items.copy: Information is kept only for as long as required for clinical, legal or regulatory reasons. Retention can differ depending on what the information relates to.

items.title: Your rights
items.copy: You have rights under UK data protection law, including the right to access your information and request corrections. If you have questions or would like to exercise your rights, please contact the practice.

sections.title: Cookies and website tools
sections.label: Overview
sections.copy: This page explains how cookies and similar technologies may be used on our website. Cookies are small files stored on your device that help a site work properly, remember preferences, and (where enabled) provide usage insights. Some cookies are essential for core site functions and security. Others may be used for analytics to understand which pages are visited and how the site performs. Optional cookies, if used, can be managed through your browser settings. You can also manage cookies through your browser settings, although this may affect how some features behave.

items.title: What this page covers
items.copy: A summary of how cookies and related tools may operate on the website and what their purposes are.

items.title: Key points in plain English
items.copy: Highlights about essential cookies, optional analytics, and how they support site performance and preferences.

items.title: Your choices and controls
items.copy: Ways you can manage cookie settings, including consent options and browser-level controls.

items.title: How to contact us
items.copy: Where to reach the practice if you have questions or feedback about cookies on this site.

items.title: Updates to this page
items.copy: How and when we may refresh this cookies information to reflect current website behaviour.

sections.title: Using this website
sections.label: Overview
sections.copy:
These website terms explain how you may use this site and what the information here is (and isn’t) intended for.

The content on this website is provided for general information only. It is not a substitute for a dental examination, diagnosis, or personalised advice.

If you have a dental problem, pain, swelling, trauma, or anything you’re worried about, please contact the practice so we can advise you appropriately.

items.title: What this page covers
items.copy:
These terms apply to your use of this website. They cover the general informational nature of the content, responsible use of the site, and how to contact us if you have questions.

They do not replace the terms you agree to when you become a patient, and they do not form a clinical relationship on their own.

items.title: Key points in plain English
items.copy:
- You can browse and use this website for personal, lawful purposes.
- The information is general and may not apply to your specific situation.
- Dentistry often needs an examination and sometimes X-rays or scans before advice is reliable.
- If you need urgent help, please contact us rather than relying on website information.

items.title: Your choices and controls
items.copy:
You are welcome to print or share pages for personal use, but please don’t copy large parts of the site for commercial use.

If you’re making decisions about treatment, the safest route is always an appointment where we can assess you properly and explain options, limits, and likely maintenance.

items.title: How to contact us
items.copy:
If you have questions about the website content, or you believe something is unclear or out of date, please contact the practice and we’ll do our best to help.

For clinical concerns (pain, swelling, broken teeth, lost restorations, or anything urgent), please call us so we can guide you to the right next step.

items.title: Updates to this page
items.copy:
We may update these website terms from time to time to reflect changes to the site or how we provide information.

The current version will always be available on this page.

sections.title: Accessibility on our website
sections.label: Overview
sections.copy: We want our website to be usable for as many people as possible. Accessibility is an ongoing process, and we aim to improve readability, navigation, and compatibility with assistive technologies over time. If you find any part of the site difficult to use — for example, problems with contrast, text size, forms, or keyboard navigation — please let us know. Where possible, we can provide information in an alternative format and record feedback for future improvements.

items.title: Our approach
items.copy: We aim to make the website as usable as possible for as many people as possible. Accessibility is an ongoing process, and we review clarity, navigation and compatibility as the site evolves.

items.title: What you can do on your side
items.copy: Many people improve readability using browser or device settings (text size, zoom, contrast modes, reader modes, and voice control). If you’d like help finding those settings, let us know.

items.title: Known limitations
items.copy: Some third-party tools, embedded media, or older documents may not meet every accessibility standard in every situation. If you find something that isn’t working for you, we want to know so we can look at alternatives.

items.title: Alternative formats
items.copy: If you need information in a different format, we can usually provide it or talk it through. Contact the practice and tell us what would help.

items.title: Feedback and updates
items.copy: We act on feedback where we reasonably can. This page may be updated as improvements are made.

sections.title: Raising concerns
sections.label: Overview
sections.copy:
If something hasn’t felt right, we want to know.

We take complaints seriously and we aim to resolve concerns fairly, calmly, and as quickly as possible.

If you feel able, please raise the issue with us directly first. Most concerns can be resolved promptly once we understand what has happened and what you’re worried about.

items.title: What this page covers
items.copy:
This page explains how to raise a concern or complaint about care you have received, and how we handle it.

It is not a substitute for clinical advice. If you have pain, swelling, trauma, or an urgent problem, please contact the practice so we can help you quickly.

items.title: Key points in plain English
items.copy:
- Tell us what happened and what outcome you’re hoping for.
- We will listen, review what we can, and respond clearly.
- If we need time to investigate properly, we will tell you the expected timescales.
- You can raise concerns in writing, by email, or by speaking to the team.

items.title: Your choices and controls
items.copy:
You can bring someone with you to support you if you prefer.

If you would like your complaint handled by a specific person, let us know and we will do our best to accommodate this, depending on availability and the nature of the concern.

We keep complaints confidential and handle them in line with professional and legal obligations.

items.title: How to contact us
items.copy:
The best first step is to contact the practice directly so we can understand the issue and try to resolve it.

If you prefer to put things in writing, email is often the clearest way to set out what happened and what you would like us to do next.

items.title: Updates to this page
items.copy:
We may update this page from time to time to reflect how we operate or changes in guidance.

The current version will always be available on this page.

sections.title: Practice insights
sections.copy:
This is where we share practical notes and clinical insights from the practice.

Most posts are written to help you make sense of common dental concerns, what tends to cause them, and what sensible next steps usually look like. From time to time we’ll also explain how planning, scanning and modern materials can make treatment more predictable.

Everything here is general information. It can be a useful starting point, but it can’t replace advice tailored to you after an examination. If something you read here raises questions about your own teeth or gums, we’re happy to talk it through at an appointment.

---

sections.title: Secure access for patients
sections.copy: Our patient portal is designed to keep key information in one secure place — helping you stay organised before, during and after appointments. Depending on what you’re using it for, the portal may include appointment details, forms, messages, treatment plans, and helpful aftercare information. If you’re not sure whether the portal is relevant for your situation, our team can guide you. We also keep communication simple: if you prefer to speak to us directly, you can always call the practice. The portal is an optional support tool, built around clarity and convenience rather than complexity.
sections.label: Portal

sections.title: What to expect
items: Encrypted access to appointments and records

video_consultation.label: Video Consultation
video_consultation.description: Tele-dentistry guidance with clear expectations on what can be handled remotely and when to visit in person.

sections.title: Remote guidance with a clinician
sections.copy:
A video consultation can be a calm first step if you’d like clinical guidance before coming into the practice.

It works well for discussing symptoms, reviewing your history, talking through options, and planning what would be most useful to do in person. If something needs a hands-on examination, X-rays or scans, we’ll be clear about that and help you book the right appointment.

A video consultation is not designed for emergencies, significant swelling, trauma, or situations where you may need urgent clinical care. In those cases, please call us so we can advise promptly.
sections.label: Overview

sections.title: What we can cover remotely
items: Discuss discomfort, swelling, or sensitivity and assess urgency
Review recent photos or scans you can share securely
Explain likely causes and sensible self-care steps while you wait
Plan whether you need an in-practice visit and which appointment type fits best
sections.label: Scope

sections.title: What still needs the practice
items: X-rays, detailed gum checks, and restorative treatment
Hands-on examination for bite, mobility, or soft-tissue changes
Urgent care that requires medication, procedures, or immediate assessment
sections.label: Limitations

sections.title: How your video visit works
items: Share your concern and any photos when booking
Join the secure video link at the scheduled time
We listen, guide you through a visual review, and outline sensible next steps
If needed, we book you into an in-practice appointment that matches the situation
sections.label: Process

sections.title: Who this works well for
items: Concerns where you want guidance before travelling or taking time off work
Follow-up questions after a recent appointment
Accessibility needs where a pre-visit review makes the in-practice appointment more efficient
sections.label: Suitability

sections.title: Finance support without pressure
sections.copy:
Some patients prefer to spread the cost of dental treatment over time rather than paying for everything at once.

Finance can be a practical option for larger treatment plans, but it isn’t right for everyone and isn’t a requirement for treatment.

sections.title: Suitability

practice_plan.label: Practice Plan
practice_plan.description: Membership overview covering what is included, how to join, and how it supports routine care.

sections.title: Membership that keeps care consistent
sections.copy:
A dental practice plan is designed to help patients look after their oral health on an ongoing basis, rather than focusing only on treatment when problems arise.

It spreads the cost of routine dental care and encourages regular review, prevention, and early intervention where needed.

We’ll explain what is included, what isn’t, and how often appointments are recommended for you personally. If you’re comparing options, we can also talk through pay-as-you-go fees so you can choose what fits best.
sections.label: Overview

sections.title: What membership typically includes
items: Regular dental examinations and oral cancer screening
Hygiene appointments to support gum health
A clear plan for routine reviews and reminders
Support with urgent problems during opening hours where possible
sections.label: Inclusions

sections.title: How joining works
items: We review your oral health and recommend an appropriate level of routine care
If you choose to join, we complete a simple sign-up with your details
We schedule your examinations and hygiene visits at suitable intervals
We keep your recall organised with reminders so you stay on track
sections.label: Process

sections.title: Why members choose it
items: Helps keep routine care consistent, rather than reactive
Encourages earlier intervention before small issues become bigger ones
Makes it easier to plan care and spread costs over time
sections.label: Benefits

dental_checkups_oral_cancer_screening.description: Routine dental exams with calm monitoring, preventative advice, and reassuring screening.

sections.title: Gentle check-ups with attentive screening
sections.copy: We keep routine exams unhurried, explaining what we see and what it means for your mouth. We include a visual oral cancer screening at every routine exam.

sections.title: How often to book
sections.copy: Most people stay on track with 6-monthly visits. If you have higher decay or gum risk, recent treatment, or are in active orthodontic care, we may agree a shorter cadence. We explain any recommendations so you know why timing matters.
sections.label: Frequency

sections.title: If something is worrying you
sections.copy: If you notice ulcers that do not settle, new lumps, persistent soreness, or changes to your mouth or throat, contact us promptly. We will arrange a calm assessment, share what we can see, and signpost to further investigation if needed.
sections.label: Support

sections.title: Stay on track between check-ups
sections.strapline: Keep hygiene, preventative care, and family visits on a steady rhythm.

faqs.question: Do I need x-rays every time?
faqs.answer: Not always. We follow clinical guidance and your risk profile to decide when x-rays are useful. We will explain the reason, dose, and what we are looking for before taking them.

faqs.question: Will you tell me if you see anything concerning?
faqs.answer: Yes. We talk you through any changes, explain what is normal, and outline next steps if we spot something that needs a closer look.

faqs.question: How long does a routine exam take?
faqs.answer: Allow around 30 minutes so we can review your mouth carefully, capture notes or images, and leave time for your questions.

faqs.question: Can I combine a check-up with hygiene?
faqs.answer: Often yes. We can align appointments so you have your check-up and hygiene visit together when schedules allow.

sections.title: Arrange your routine dental check-up
sections.copy: Book a calm examination with oral cancer screening included. Tell us if you would like a slower pace or extra reassurance.

faqs.answer: Allow around 30 minutes so we can review your mouth carefully, capture notes or images, and leave time for your questions.

faqs.question: Can I combine a check-up with hygiene?
faqs.answer: Often yes. We can align appointments so you have your check-up and hygiene visit together when schedules allow.

sections.title: Composite bonding for measured smile refinement
sections.copy: Composite bonding (also called cosmetic bonding or dental bonding) uses layered resin to rebuild edges and balance shapes with minimal drilling. We preserve enamel wherever possible, plan conservatively, and explain how wear and staining can be managed over time.
bullets: Tooth-preserving contouring with light surface preparation
Resins layered to match shade, translucency, and texture
Calm appointment pacing with time for review before final polishing

sections.title: Conservative improvements, well planned
sections.label: Introduction
sections.copy: Composite bonding uses tooth-coloured resin to improve shape, close small gaps, repair chips, or soften uneven edges. It can often be done with minimal drilling, making it a conservative option when the bite and enamel are suitable. We begin with an assessment of wear, staining, gum health and bite forces, because those factors determine how predictable bonding will be over time. For some patients, whitening or aligner straightening first can improve the final result and reduce the amount of composite needed. If bonding is a good fit, we’ll explain what it can achieve, how it’s maintained, and what to expect with polishing and repairs.

sections.title: What composite bonding can and can’t do
items: Adds volume to close small gaps, soften edges, and refine proportions without drilling healthy enamel
Repairs chipped or worn incisal edges; larger fractures or weakened teeth may need onlays or crowns
Helps smooth minor rotations and asymmetry, but major crowding still needs aligners or orthodontics
Can mask shade variations to a degree, yet deep discolouration often responds better to whitening or veneers
Composite will pick up surface stain and light wear; expect periodic polishing to keep results fresh

sections.label: Digital planning
sections.title: Digitally planned and guided bonding
sections.copy: We start with 3D scans and photographs, design the proposed changes digitally, and share mock-ups so you can preview the direction. Guided placement and finishing maps keep the resin precise and consistent, and set up injection moulding when it is the safest choice.
sections.mediaHint: Digital smile planning and mock-up visuals

sections.title: Injection moulding technique
sections.copy: Injection moulded composite uses digital design and silicone or printed keys to deliver resin through a precise guide. It keeps edge lengths, embrasures, and widths consistent, improves symmetry across multiple teeth, and reduces chairside guesswork.
bullets: Digital scans and wax-ups map planned tooth shapes before treatment
Silicone keys or printed guides control resin volume for repeatable placement
Predictable edge lengths and contact points with fewer mid-appointment adjustments
Efficient when treating several teeth together or refining symmetry after orthodontics

sections.title: How composite bonding fits with other options
items: When colour is the main concern, dentist-led whitening is usually recommended before bonding so shades align
If teeth are rotated or crowded, aligners or other orthodontic treatment can set the foundation before cosmetic bonding
For larger shape changes or durability, porcelain veneers or digitally designed 3D veneers may be more appropriate
Composite bonding often forms part of an Align → Bleach → Composite pathway, with veneers reserved for specific needs

sections.title: Longevity & maintenance
items: Professional polishing restores gloss and smoothness without replacing the whole restoration
Small chips or edge wear can usually be touched up chairside to extend lifespan
Night guards help protect edges if you clench or grind, reducing fracture risk
Coffee, tea, red wine, and smoking increase staining; hygiene visits and mindful habits keep colour stable

sections.title: When bonding isn’t the best choice
items: Heavy bites or active clenching with limited space may need occlusal therapy or guards first
Severe wear or bite collapse often requires orthodontics, onlays, or veneers for stability
Deep discolouration or large colour jumps are better addressed with whitening or porcelain coverage
Insufficient enamel or untreated gum disease must be managed before cosmetic bonding is planned

faqs.question: How long does composite bonding last?
faqs.answer: With regular hygiene visits, polishing, and a night guard if you clench, many cases stay stable for several years before refreshes are needed.

faqs.question: Can composite bonding be repaired?
faqs.answer: Yes. Chips or edge wear can usually be smoothed and re-layered without removing the rest of the bonding, keeping treatment conservative.

faqs.question: How do I maintain bonded teeth?
faqs.answer: Use non-abrasive toothpaste, attend hygienist visits for polishing, minimise staining foods and smoking, and wear a night guard if advised.

faqs.question: Is composite bonding suitable for everyone?
faqs.answer: Suitability depends on bite forces, enamel quality, and goals. We may recommend whitening, aligners, or veneers instead if the bite is heavy or colour change needed is significant.

sections.title: Who composite bonding suits best
items: Patients wanting cosmetic improvement without irreversible drilling

Patients who value reversible changes and measured maintenance

sections.title: Strength, function, and maintainability
sections.label: Introduction
sections.copy: A dental crown is a protective restoration that covers and strengthens a tooth that is heavily filled, cracked, worn down, or has had root canal treatment. The goal is to restore function and protect the remaining tooth structure, while keeping the bite comfortable and the margins clean and maintainable. We plan crowns using a full assessment and digital scans so we can check contact points, bite forces and appearance before anything is finalised. Where appropriate, we’ll discuss onlays or adhesive options that preserve more natural tooth. If a crown is recommended, we’ll explain materials, preparation, and how to look after it.

faqs.answer: Whitening gels can temporarily increase fluid movement within the tooth. We control gel strength and contact time to keep this minimal.

faqs.question: Can I still whiten if I already feel sensitivity?

faqs.question: What should I do if I feel a zing?
faqs.answer: Pause for a day or two and let us know. We can adjust frequency, recommend relief products, or review fit.

faqs.question: Does whitening damage teeth?
faqs.answer: When prescribed and monitored by a dentist using UK-regulated gels, whitening is safe for enamel. We assess for decay or gum issues first and use protective trays.

faqs.question: How white can teeth go?
faqs.answer: We aim for a natural, even shade that suits your skin tone and enamel. Shade maps set a realistic range so we avoid over-whitening.

faqs.question: Does whitening affect veneers or crowns?
faqs.answer: Existing crowns, veneers, and fillings will not lighten. We plan whitening first, then match or refresh restorations if needed.

faqs.question: How long does whitening last?
faqs.answer: Results are maintained with good hygiene and occasional top-ups. We’ll guide you on a safe refresh schedule using your existing trays.

faqs.question: Is whitening part of a smile makeover?
faqs.answer: Often yes. Whitening is the “B” in our Align, Bleach, Composite approach so colour is set before aligning teeth or adding bonding.

sections.title: Smile makeovers guided by a shared plan
sections.copy:
A full smile makeover is a way of looking at your teeth together, rather than treating individual problems in isolation. People often come to us with a mix of concerns — how their teeth look, how they function, or how they’ve changed over time.

Rather than jumping straight to treatment, we start by understanding what matters to you and what’s realistically achievable. In many cases, there is more than one way forward. Some options are simpler and more conservative, while others are more involved and take longer.

Our role is to help you understand those options clearly, including their limits, so you can decide what feels right for you.

---
bullets: Plan designed from scans and photos
Sequence options reviewed together
Checkpoints keep outcomes aligned

sections.label: Plan canvas
sections.title: Preview the makeover path
sections.copy:
Planning is the most important part of any smile makeover. This usually involves careful examination, photographs, scans, and discussion, rather than making quick decisions.

This stage helps us see how your teeth fit together, where changes may be helpful, and where they may not be appropriate. It also allows time to talk through expectations and agree a plan that makes sense before any treatment starts.

---

sections.label: Planning tools
sections.title: Tools that keep complex plans clear
sections.copy:
A full smile makeover is usually built up in stages. Each stage has a purpose, and not every stage is needed for every person. The aim is to move forward in a controlled way, rather than trying to do everything at once.

Some stages focus on creating space or alignment, others on improving appearance or repairing wear. We plan these steps carefully so that earlier treatment supports what comes later.

---

items.title: Digital smile design
items.description: We start by understanding your concerns, examining your teeth and bite, and discussing what you’d like to change. This helps identify which problems need addressing first and which can be left alone.

items.title: Phase timeline
items.description: Where needed, early treatment may focus on alignment, bite position, or stabilising the teeth. These steps often make later cosmetic or restorative work more predictable.

items.title: Photo and scan tracking
items.description: Final stages may involve improving shape, colour, or repairing damage. The exact treatments depend on the plan agreed earlier and are tailored to your individual situation.

sections.label: Clinician insight
sections.quote:
A full smile makeover isn’t a single treatment. It’s a way of planning several treatments together so they work well as a whole.

What that involves varies from person to person. For some, it may focus on alignment and tooth position. For others, it may involve whitening, bonding, veneers or restorative work to address wear, damage or long-standing problems.

The most important part is the assessment and planning stage. We take time to understand what’s bothering you, examine your teeth and bite carefully, and look at what is realistically achievable. In many cases, treatment is staged over time rather than rushed.

Not everyone needs a full smile makeover. Sometimes smaller, simpler steps can make a meaningful difference. Part of our role is helping you understand the options, the limitations, and what makes sense for you in the long term.

stories.summary: “I wanted to improve how my teeth looked, but I was nervous about doing too much. We talked through different options and took things step by step, which made the whole process feel manageable.”
stories.name: Case P

stories.summary: “My teeth had worn over time and I wasn’t sure what could realistically be done. The planning stage helped me understand what was possible and what wasn’t, before deciding how far to go.”
stories.name: Case Q

stories.summary: “I didn’t want anything rushed. Having time to think things through and spread treatment out made a big difference to how comfortable I felt.”
stories.name: Case R

sections.title: Related care to explore
sections.strapline: If you’re considering a full smile makeover, the first step is a conversation. An assessment allows us to look at your teeth properly and talk through whether this approach makes sense for you.

faqs.question: Who is a full smile makeover for?
faqs.answer: It may be suitable for people with several concerns they’d like to address together, such as worn, discoloured, misaligned or damaged teeth. An assessment is needed to see whether this approach is appropriate.

faqs.question: What treatments might be involved?
faqs.answer: Depending on your needs, this could include orthodontic treatment, whitening, bonding, veneers, crowns or other restorative work. Not every treatment is needed for every person.

faqs.question: How long does it take?
faqs.answer: Timeframes vary. Some treatment plans take a few months, while others are staged over a longer period. We’ll talk this through during planning so you know what to expect.

faqs.question: Are there alternatives?
faqs.answer: Yes. In many cases, more limited treatment can still improve appearance or function. We’ll discuss alternatives and the likely trade-offs.

faqs.question: How long do results last?
faqs.answer: Longevity depends on the treatments used, how your teeth are looked after, and factors such as grinding or diet. Ongoing care and maintenance are important.

sections.title: Plan a full smile makeover
sections.strapline: A consultation is an opportunity to ask questions, understand your options, and decide what feels right for you, without any obligation to proceed.
