sections.title: Emergency dentistry
sections.copy:
If you’re in pain, have swelling, or you’ve damaged a tooth, the first job is to work out what’s urgent and what’s fixable — calmly.

Emergency care is usually about stabilising the situation: getting you comfortable, reducing risk, and planning the right longer-term repair.

If you’re unsure whether you need to be seen quickly, contact us and we’ll guide you.
bullets: Assess what’s happening and how urgent it is
Settle pain and stabilise the problem safely
Explain the next step and the longer-term plan

sections.title: How we handle dental emergencies
sections.label: Introduction
sections.copy:
Dental problems rarely arrive at a convenient time.

We’ll listen to what’s happening, ask a few focused questions, and advise whether it sounds urgent. If you need to be seen, we’ll aim to book the right type of appointment rather than squeeze you into the wrong slot.

If there are signs of a serious spreading infection (rapid facial swelling, fever, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems), seek urgent medical help immediately (A&E / 999) and then let us know as soon as you can.

sections.title: Common reasons people contact us urgently
items: Severe toothache or pain that is worsening or disrupting sleep
Swelling of the gum, face, or jaw
A broken, cracked, or sharply chipped tooth
A crown, veneer, or filling that has come out and is painful or sharp
Dental trauma after an accident (loose, displaced, or knocked-out tooth)

sections.title: What to do right now
items: Contact us with a short description of what’s happened, where the pain is, and how long it has been going on
Use normal pain relief if safe for you (follow the packet guidance) and avoid chewing on the painful side
If you develop facial swelling, fever, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems, seek urgent medical help

sections.label: Common emergency situations
sections.title: What you can expect at an emergency visit
sections.copy:
We’ll focus on diagnosis and stabilisation.

That usually means an examination (and X-rays if needed), clear explanation of what we can see, and the least invasive step that reduces pain and risk. Sometimes that’s a temporary measure with a planned follow-up. Sometimes it’s a definitive repair — it depends on the tooth and the cause.

We’ll explain costs and options before anything starts, so you can make a clear decision under pressure.

sections.title: After an emergency visit
sections.copy:
Following emergency care, further treatment may be recommended to address the underlying cause.

We’ll explain any findings clearly and discuss whether monitoring, further investigation, or planned treatment is appropriate.

You’ll have time to consider options once the immediate situation has settled.

sections.title: Related care to explore
sections.strapline: Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.

sections.title: When urgent care may not be necessary

faqs.question: When urgent care may not be necessary
faqs.answer:
Some issues can wait a short time — for example, a small chip with no pain, a lost filling that isn’t sensitive, or mild sensitivity that settles quickly.

If you’re unsure, it’s still worth contacting us. We can help you work out whether it sounds urgent, and what to do while you’re waiting.

faqs.question: Questions and reassurance
faqs.answer:
If you’re anxious, tell us. We’ll take things step-by-step, explain what we’re doing, and keep the plan simple.

Emergency dentistry isn’t about pressure-selling or starting big treatment on the spot. It’s about getting you safe, comfortable, and clear on the next sensible step.

sections.title: Call for emergency dental care
sections.strapline: Contact us for advice or an emergency appointment.

sections.title: Emergency dental appointments
sections.copy:
If you’re in pain, have swelling, or you’ve damaged a tooth, an emergency appointment is about stabilising the situation.

That usually means diagnosis, getting you comfortable, reducing risk, and agreeing the next sensible step. Sometimes we can fix the problem on the day. Sometimes the safest care is staged.

We’ll explain what we can see, what’s realistic, and what you can do next — without pressure.
bullets: Work out what’s happening and how urgent it is
Relieve pain and stabilise the tooth or gum
Reduce risk of infection or worsening symptoms
Plan the next step clearly and realistically

sections.copy:
Dental problems rarely happen at a convenient time.

If you’re not sure whether you need to be seen urgently, contact us. We’ll ask a few focused questions and advise timing.

If you have rapid facial swelling, fever, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems, seek urgent medical help immediately (A&E / 999) and then let us know as soon as you can.

sections.title: Common reasons people request an emergency visit
items: Severe toothache or pain that disrupts sleep
Swelling of the gum, face, or jaw
A broken, cracked, or sharply chipped tooth
A crown, veneer, or filling that has come out and is painful or sharp
Dental trauma after an accident (loose, displaced, or knocked-out tooth)

sections.title: What to do now
items: Contact us and describe what’s happened, where the pain is, and how long it has been going on
Use normal pain relief if safe for you (follow the packet guidance)
Avoid chewing on the painful side and stick to softer foods
If swelling, fever, or swallowing/breathing issues develop, seek urgent medical help

sections.title: Why assessment matters
sections.copy:
Emergency care works best when we diagnose the cause properly, not just the symptom.

Pain can come from decay, infection, cracks, gum problems, or failed restorations — and the right solution depends on what we find.

Seeing you early often gives more conservative options, better comfort, and fewer repeat flare-ups.
sections.label: Prompt care
What we can do
sections.title: What an emergency appointment can involve
sections.copy:
An emergency visit usually includes an examination and, where appropriate, X-rays to understand what’s happening under the surface.

We’ll explain the likely cause, discuss options and costs, and agree the safest next step. That might be a temporary stabilisation, a simple repair, or a plan for staged treatment.

Our aim is clarity, comfort, and a sensible route forward.

sections.title: Related care to explore
sections.strapline: Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.

faqs.question: Can you always fix the problem on the day?
faqs.answer: Not always — it depends on the cause and what’s safest for the tooth. Sometimes we can provide a definitive repair. Other times the priority is stabilisation and pain control, followed by a planned appointment for the longer-term fix. We’ll explain this clearly at the visit.

faqs.question: What if I am nervous about urgent treatment?
faqs.answer: Tell us. We’ll take a calm, step-by-step approach: clear explanation, breaks if you need them, and a plan that feels manageable. Emergency dentistry isn’t about rushing you — it’s about getting you safe and comfortable.

faqs.question: Do I need a referral for an emergency visit?
faqs.answer: No. You can contact the practice directly. If we think you need another service urgently (for example, medical assessment after trauma or signs of a serious spreading infection), we’ll tell you clearly and help you choose the safest next step.

sections.title: Call for an emergency appointment
sections.strapline: Tell us what has happened so we can reserve time and guide you before you travel.

sections.title: Severe toothache and dental pain
sections.copy:
Severe toothache can feel urgent, and it’s hard to think about anything else. Here in Shoreham-by-Sea, we see how quickly pain can disrupt sleep, eating, and work.

Pain relief can help you cope, but it doesn’t fix the underlying cause. Toothache can come from decay, infection, cracks, gum problems, grinding, or a filling or crown that’s failed.

We’ll assess what’s going on, explain what we can see, and recommend the most sensible way to settle pain and protect the tooth.
bullets: Identify the cause of pain
Relieve discomfort safely
Prevent the problem from worsening
Plan a realistic, durable fix

sections.copy:
Toothache can range from mild twinges to severe, throbbing pain that disrupts sleep. If it’s persistent, worsening, or triggered by biting, heat, or cold, it’s worth getting checked even if it comes and goes.

We can talk through what’s happening and advise timing. If pain is getting worse, you notice swelling, fever, a bad taste, or you cannot open your mouth comfortably, call us promptly.

If you have rapid facial swelling, fever, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems, seek urgent medical help immediately (A&E / 999) and then let us know as soon as you can.

sections.title: Common signs
items: Constant or throbbing tooth pain
Sharp pain on biting or when you release the bite
Sensitivity to hot, cold, or sweet foods
Pain that wakes you or lingers after triggers
Swelling, bad taste, or pain spreading to the jaw or ear

sections.title: What to do now
items: Contact us so we can advise urgency and book the right appointment
Use normal pain relief if safe for you (follow the packet guidance)
Keep the area clean with gentle brushing and warm salt-water rinses
Avoid chewing on the painful side and stick to softer foods
If you develop facial swelling, fever, or difficulty swallowing, seek urgent medical help

sections.title: Why assessment matters
sections.copy:
Pain often means the tooth or surrounding tissues are under stress.

Painkillers and temporary measures can take the edge off, but they cannot resolve infection, nerve damage, or structural problems such as cracks or failed restorations. The safest route is a proper assessment so the right treatment is chosen for you.

Our aim is to diagnose the cause accurately, settle pain, and help you avoid repeat flare-ups.
sections.label: Prompt relief
What we can do
sections.title: Possible treatments
sections.copy:
At an emergency appointment we start with an assessment, look for the cause, and confirm a diagnosis with any checks or X-rays needed.

Where appropriate we provide immediate stabilisation to relieve pain and protect the tooth. Not all treatment is completed in one visit, so we’ll outline the next stages and timing.

Options may include replacing or repairing a filling, root canal treatment to treat infection inside the tooth, gum treatment, adjusting the bite, or in some cases removing a tooth that can’t be predictably saved.

We’ll explain the findings and the pros and cons of each option before anything is done.

sections.title: Related care to explore
sections.strapline: Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.

faqs.question: Can I wait to see if the pain settles?
faqs.answer: Sometimes pain eases for a while, but the cause may still be there. If pain is severe, waking you, lingering, or getting worse, it’s best to get advice promptly. Contact us and we’ll guide you on timing.

faqs.question: Will treatment be painful?
faqs.answer: Our aim is to get you comfortable first. We use effective local anaesthetic and we work in a calm, step-by-step way. If you’re anxious, tell us — pacing, breaks, and clear explanation make a big difference.

faqs.question: What if the pain starts overnight?
faqs.answer: Use normal pain relief if safe for you (follow the packet guidance), keep the area clean, and avoid chewing on that side. If you develop swelling, fever, or difficulty swallowing/breathing, seek urgent medical help. Contact us as soon as we’re open and we’ll advise next steps.

sections.title: Arrange urgent toothache care
sections.strapline: We will guide you on immediate steps and bring you in quickly to relieve pain.

sections.title: Dental abscess and infection
sections.copy:
A dental abscess is an infection that can build pressure and cause significant pain, swelling, or a bad taste.

Sometimes symptoms come and go, but the underlying infection usually needs proper assessment and treatment. Leaving it can allow the infection to spread and can make the tooth harder to save.

If you have facial swelling, difficulty swallowing, fever, or you feel generally unwell, seek urgent advice and contact us as soon as possible.
bullets: Assess the cause and how urgent it is
Reduce pain and pressure safely
Treat infection appropriately (not just symptoms)
Plan the most sensible long-term fix

sections.copy:
Infections can start quietly — sometimes as a dull ache, sometimes as sensitivity, and sometimes with no pain until swelling appears.

An abscess can come from the tooth nerve, from gum disease, or from a crack or deep decay letting bacteria in.

If you’re unsure whether it’s an emergency, call us. We can advise on urgency and what to do while you’re waiting to be seen.

sections.title: Common signs
items: Throbbing toothache or pain that wakes you
Swelling of the gum, face, or jaw
A bad taste, pus, or a spot on the gum that drains
Pain on biting or a tooth that feels raised
Fever, feeling unwell, or swollen glands (seek urgent advice)

sections.title: What to do now
items: Contact us promptly so we can advise urgency and book the right appointment
Use normal pain relief if needed and safe for you (follow the packet guidance)
Warm salt-water rinses can help comfort (do not apply heat to facial swelling)
Avoid chewing on that side and stick to softer foods
If you develop facial swelling, fever, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems, seek urgent medical help

sections.title: Why it needs proper assessment
sections.copy:
Infections are not always solved by antibiotics alone. Antibiotics may be appropriate in certain situations, but the source of the infection usually needs treating.

That might mean draining the infection, cleaning and sealing the tooth with root canal treatment, treating gum infection, or removing a tooth that cannot be saved.

Our job is to assess the cause, explain the realistic options, and help you get stable quickly — then plan longer-term care calmly.
sections.label: Act early
What we can do
sections.title: Possible treatments
sections.copy:
Treatment depends on where the infection is coming from and how advanced it is.

Options may include local measures to relieve pressure, root canal treatment to save a tooth, periodontal (gum) treatment, or extraction where the tooth cannot be predictably restored.

If antibiotics are needed, we’ll explain why, what they can and can’t do, and what follow-up is required.

sections.title: Related care to explore
sections.strapline: Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.

faqs.question: Do I always need antibiotics?
faqs.answer: Sometimes antibiotics are necessary, especially if there is spreading swelling or you are unwell. But an abscess usually needs the source treated as well — for example drainage, root canal treatment, gum treatment, or extraction. We’ll advise what’s appropriate after assessment.

faqs.question: Will the swelling go away on its own?
faqs.answer: Symptoms can ease if an abscess drains, but the infection often remains and can flare again. Leaving it can increase risk of spread and reduce the chance of saving the tooth. It’s safest to get it assessed.

faqs.question: Can I work or travel after treatment?
faqs.answer: Facial swelling can be serious. Contact us urgently. If you have fever, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems, seek urgent medical help immediately (A&E / 999) and then update us as soon as you can.

sections.title: Get help for swelling or infection
sections.strapline: Call now so we can assess and relieve the infection safely.

sections.title: Broken, chipped or cracked teeth
sections.copy:
If you’ve chipped a tooth, cracked a corner, or something feels sharp or painful, it’s worth getting it checked promptly.

Some problems look small but involve deeper cracks or exposed dentine, which can lead to sensitivity, infection, or a larger fracture.

We’ll assess what’s happened, explain what we can see, and recommend the least invasive repair that keeps the tooth stable.
bullets: Quick smoothing to prevent cuts to cheeks or tongue
Temporary coverings where needed
Assessment for structural stability
Clear plan for lasting repairs

sections.copy:
Teeth can chip or crack for lots of reasons — biting something hard, an old filling giving way, grinding, or an accident.

Sometimes it’s mainly cosmetic. Sometimes it’s an early warning that the tooth is under stress.

If you’re unsure, we’d rather you call and ask. We can advise whether it sounds urgent and what to do in the meantime.

sections.title: Common signs
items: A sharp edge that catches your tongue or floss
Pain on biting or when you release the bite
Sensitivity to cold, sweet foods, or air
A visible crack, chip, or missing corner/filling
Swelling, a bad taste, or persistent throbbing pain

sections.title: What to do now
items: Avoid chewing on that side and stick to softer foods
Keep the area clean with gentle brushing and warm salt-water rinses
If a sharp edge is cutting you, cover it temporarily with sugar-free gum or dental wax
Use your normal pain relief if needed and safe for you (follow the packet guidance)
Call us so we can advise timing and book the right appointment

sections.title: Why it’s worth checking
sections.copy:
A chip or crack isn’t always an emergency, but it can change quickly.

Small fractures can spread, and exposed dentine can become very sensitive. In some cases, cracks allow bacteria to reach the nerve, leading to infection.

Seeing you early gives us more conservative options — and helps prevent the problem turning into a bigger repair.
sections.label: Protect the tooth
What we can do
sections.title: Possible treatments
sections.copy:
Treatment depends on where the crack is, how deep it goes, and how much tooth is missing.

Options may include smoothing a sharp edge, a bonded repair (composite), replacing or reshaping an old filling, or protecting the tooth with an onlay or crown.

If the nerve is involved, root canal treatment may be needed — but we only recommend that when it’s clearly indicated.

sections.title: Related care to explore
sections.strapline: Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.

faqs.question: Can a chipped tooth wait?
faqs.answer: Sometimes a small chip can wait a short time, but it’s best to get advice. Chips can expose dentine, increase sensitivity, or develop into a larger fracture. Call us and we’ll guide you on timing.

faqs.question: Will I need a crown straight away?
faqs.answer: Not always. We usually start with the least invasive repair that keeps the tooth stable. That may be smoothing, a bonded repair, or replacing a filling. A crown or onlay is recommended when the tooth needs extra protection.

faqs.question: Is it safe to keep eating?
faqs.answer: Try to avoid chewing on the affected side until we’ve assessed the tooth. Softer foods and careful cleaning help. If biting triggers sharp pain, stop and contact us as that can suggest a deeper crack.

sections.title: Book care for a chipped or cracked tooth
sections.strapline: We will protect the tooth, relieve sensitivity, and plan the right repair.

sections.title: Knocked-out tooth
sections.copy:
A knocked-out adult tooth can sometimes be saved, but timing and handling matter.

If you can get advice immediately, bring the tooth with you and avoid touching the root. If it’s safe to do so, gentle first aid can improve the chances of a good outcome — but it isn’t always possible in real life, especially after an accident.

Call us straight away so we can guide you on what to do next and how urgently you need to be seen.
bullets: Act quickly — time matters
Handle the tooth carefully (avoid the root)
Keep it moist and protected
Get assessed promptly for the best chance of stabilisation

sections.copy:
Having a tooth knocked out is frightening — and it often happens alongside a fall, collision, or sports injury.

If the tooth is an adult tooth, there may be a chance of replantation depending on timing and what’s happened to the tooth and socket.

If you’re unsure whether it’s a baby tooth or an adult tooth, or there are other injuries, call us and we’ll guide you to the safest next step.

sections.title: Common signs
items: A tooth completely out of the mouth
Bleeding from the socket or gum
Pain, swelling, or a cut lip/cheek alongside the injury
A tooth that feels loose or displaced after impact

sections.title: What to do now
items: Check for head injury, heavy bleeding, or breathing problems and seek urgent medical help if needed
Find the tooth, pick it up by the crown (not the root), and avoid scrubbing it
If it’s dirty, rinse gently for a few seconds with milk or saline (avoid disinfectants)
Keep it moist: ideally in milk, saline, or inside the cheek if safe (not in water)
Call us immediately so we can advise urgency and prepare for assessment

sections.title: Why speed matters
sections.copy:
The tissues that help an adult tooth reattach can be damaged quickly if the tooth dries out or is handled roughly.

Even with prompt care, replantation isn’t always possible or successful — but early assessment usually gives the best chance of stabilising the situation and planning next steps.

We’ll also check for associated injuries, fractures, and whether nearby teeth have been damaged or loosened.
sections.label: Act quickly
What we can do
sections.title: Possible treatments
sections.copy:
Treatment depends on whether the tooth is an adult tooth, how long it has been out, how it has been stored, and the condition of the socket and surrounding bone.

Options may include careful replantation and stabilisation (splinting) where appropriate, monitoring healing, and follow-up assessment. In some situations, replacement options are discussed if replantation isn’t possible.

We’ll explain the likely risks, the aftercare required, and what long-term maintenance might involve.

sections.title: Related care to explore
sections.strapline: Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.

faqs.question: Can a baby tooth be replanted?
faqs.answer: Usually no. Baby (primary) teeth are not normally replanted because doing so can damage the developing adult tooth underneath. If you’re unsure whether it’s a baby or adult tooth, call us and we’ll advise quickly.

faqs.question: What if the tooth looks damaged?
faqs.answer: If the tooth is broken, cracked, or has obvious contamination, replantation may be less suitable — but it depends on the situation. Keep the tooth safe and moist, avoid touching the root, and contact us so we can assess what’s realistic.

faqs.question: Do I need a tetanus check?
faqs.answer: If the injury involved a dirty wound, soil, or a cut that may have been contaminated, a tetanus check may be sensible. If you’re unsure, contact your GP, NHS 111, or urgent care for advice — and still contact us so we can deal with the dental side promptly.

sections.title: Call immediately about a knocked-out tooth
sections.strapline: We will guide you on safe handling and prepare to see you right away.

sections.title: Lost crowns, veneers or fillings
sections.copy:
If a crown, veneer or filling has come out, it can feel urgent — especially if the tooth is sensitive or looks unfinished.

In many cases the tooth can be protected and repaired conservatively, but timing matters. A lost restoration can leave sharp edges, exposed dentine, or a tooth that is more likely to fracture.

We’ll assess what’s happened, explain the options clearly, and help you stabilise the tooth as simply as possible.
bullets: Protect the tooth and reduce sensitivity
Check for decay, cracks, or a cause for the failure
Decide whether it can be re-cemented or needs replacing
Restore comfort, function, and stability

sections.copy:
Restorations can come loose for lots of reasons — wear over time, biting something hard, decay underneath, or the tooth changing shape.

Sometimes it’s a straightforward re-cement. Sometimes it’s a sign the tooth needs a different kind of protection.

If you still have the crown or veneer, keep it safe and bring it with you. We can often learn a lot from seeing it.

sections.title: Common signs
items: A missing crown, veneer, inlay/onlay or filling
Sensitivity to cold, air, or sweet foods
A sharp edge catching your tongue
Pain on biting or a change in how your teeth meet
Bad taste, food trapping, or a looseness you can feel

sections.title: What to do now
items: Keep the area clean with gentle brushing and warm salt-water rinses
Avoid chewing on that side and stick to softer foods
If the tooth is sharp, cover it temporarily with sugar-free gum or dental wax
Keep the crown/veneer if you have it and bring it with you (don’t force it back on)
Call us so we can advise urgency and book the right appointment

sections.title: Why it’s worth seeing us promptly
sections.copy:
When a restoration comes out, the underlying tooth is often more vulnerable than it looks.

Exposed dentine can be very sensitive, and the tooth can fracture more easily — especially if it’s already heavily filled. If there is decay or a crack underneath, delaying can reduce the options.

Seeing you early helps us protect the tooth, manage discomfort, and plan a repair that lasts.
sections.label: Protect exposed teeth
What we can do
sections.title: Possible treatments
sections.copy:
The right solution depends on why the restoration came out and what the tooth looks like underneath.

Options may include re-cementing the existing crown or veneer (if it’s intact and the fit is still appropriate), replacing a filling, or making a new restoration if the tooth needs better protection.

If decay or a crack is present, we’ll explain the findings and the most sensible way to stabilise the tooth long-term.

sections.title: Related care to explore
sections.strapline: Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.

faqs.question: Can I eat before the appointment?
faqs.answer: Sometimes, yes. If the crown is intact and the tooth underneath is healthy and stable, re-cementing can be a good option. If decay, a crack, or fit issues are present, replacing the crown may be safer long-term.

faqs.question: Will you reuse my crown or veneer?
faqs.answer: In most cases, swallowed dental restorations pass through without causing harm. If you have breathing symptoms, chest pain, or you think it may have been inhaled, seek urgent medical advice. Either way, contact us so we can protect the tooth and plan the next step.

faqs.question: Is it urgent if I have no pain?
faqs.answer: Temporary dental cements can sometimes help short-term, but they can also trap bacteria if used incorrectly. The safest approach is to keep the area clean, avoid chewing on that side, and call us. If you do use a temporary product, treat it as a short stop-gap, not a fix.

sections.title: Book help for a lost restoration
sections.strapline: We will protect the tooth, discuss repair options, and get you back to comfort.

sections.title: Care after dental trauma or accidents
sections.copy: Falls, sports injuries, or other accidents can affect teeth and soft tissues. We provide calm assessment, stop bleeding, protect damaged areas, and outline any further treatment.
bullets: Gentle checks for teeth, gums, and jaw
Advice on cleaning and swelling control
Temporary stabilisation if needed
Clear next steps for definitive care

sections.copy: Dental trauma can range from chipped enamel to displaced or loosened teeth, fractures, and injuries to gums or supporting bone. What matters most is prompt assessment: we check tooth stability, nerve response, bite changes and soft tissue injury, and take X-rays to rule out hidden fractures. Treatment might include smoothing or repairing a chip, splinting a tooth, dressing an exposed nerve, or planning follow-up care if the tooth’s nerve is at risk. We’ll also advise on pain control and what to avoid while the area heals. If a tooth has been knocked out, time is critical — see that page for immediate steps.

sections.title: What you might notice
items: Bleeding from gums or lips
Loose or displaced teeth
Chips, cracks, or fractures
Cuts inside the mouth
Jaw soreness after impact

sections.title: What to do now
items: If bleeding, apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth or gauze
Rinse with cool water to clear debris
Save any tooth fragments or restorations
Use a cold compress on the outside of the cheek to reduce swelling
Contact us promptly; seek urgent medical help if you suspect other injuries

sections.title: Why prompt assessment helps
sections.copy: Early evaluation lets us stabilise teeth, check for hidden fractures, and plan repairs before complications develop. It also helps us coordinate with medical teams if needed.
sections.label: Early checks
What we can do
sections.title: Stabilise and plan recovery
sections.copy: Treatment may include smoothing edges, splinting loose teeth, placing temporary coverings, prescribing medication, or coordinating imaging and follow-up restorative care.

sections.title: Related care to explore
sections.strapline: Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.

faqs.question: Do I need X-rays after an accident?
faqs.answer: We will advise after examining the area. Imaging helps check for fractures or root damage that are not visible.

faqs.question: What if a tooth feels loose?
faqs.answer: Keep it clean, avoid wiggling it, and contact us. We may splint it to nearby teeth while it heals.

faqs.question: Can you help with mouth cuts?
faqs.answer: Yes. We assess soft tissue injuries, clean the area, and advise if medical attention or stitches are needed.

sections.title: Arrange care after dental trauma
sections.strapline: We will check for hidden issues, stabilise your teeth, and guide recovery.

sections.title: Prevention-first dentistry that keeps teeth for life
sections.body: Regular exams, calm explanations, and thoughtful hygiene support help you avoid problems and keep your smile comfortable for the long term.
bullets: Gentle, unhurried check-ups with the same clinical team
Prevention plans tailored to your enamel, gums, and lifestyle
Clear guidance if you’re anxious or prefer slower appointments

sections.title: Protect teeth before problems arise
items: Prevention-first mindset: preserve natural tooth structure wherever possible
Routine reviews that track subtle changes in enamel, gums, and bite
Comfort-focused care so you feel confident attending regularly
Advice that matches your habits, home care, and medical history
Clear onward pathways when you need restorative or specialist support

sections.title: Every check-up is detailed and documented
sections.body: We map your teeth, gums, and bite at each visit so we can spot issues early. Records are updated calmly with time for your questions.
bullets: Oral cancer screening at every check-up
Gum assessment to track inflammation or recession
Bite and jaw comfort review with referral to TMJ care when needed (/treatments/tmj-jaw-comfort)
Digital photos and scans where appropriate to monitor changes

sections.title: Professional hygiene that supports home care
items: Gentle, thorough cleaning to remove plaque and hardened tartar
Polishing and airflow-style finishing where suitable for stain control
Tips to improve brushing and interdental cleaning at home
Why visits matter even if you brush well: hidden build-up and hard-to-reach areas
Preventing gum disease and bad breath with tailored intervals—see periodontal care (/treatments/periodontal-gum-care)
sections.strapline: Regular hygiene keeps gums healthy and helps fillings, crowns, and implants last longer.

sections.title: Simple, science-led guidance you can follow
sections.body: We create a plan that fits your daily routine so small adjustments have a big impact.
bullets: Fluoride advice matched to your risk level—no pushy sales

faqs.question: How often should I come?
faqs.answer: Most patients attend every 6 months, but we may suggest shorter or longer gaps based on gum health, decay risk, and how quickly plaque builds for you.

faqs.question: Do you check for mouth cancer?
faqs.answer: Yes. Oral cancer screening is part of every exam. We review soft tissues, lymph areas, and any changes you’ve noticed.

faqs.question: I’m nervous — can you go slowly?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. Tell us ahead of time and we’ll pace the visit, explain each step, and link you to our nervous patient support if helpful (/treatments/nervous-patients).

faqs.question: Is home whitening better?
faqs.answer: Dentist-led whitening is usually safer and more predictable. We assess your teeth first and can advise on supervised home whitening through our whitening hub (/treatments/teeth-whitening).

faqs.question: When should my child first visit?
faqs.answer: We’re happy to see children as soon as their first teeth appear or by their first birthday. Early visits help them get used to the chair and let us spot any early issues.

faqs.question: How often should they come?
faqs.answer: Most children benefit from 6-monthly check-ups, but we may recommend shorter intervals if decay risk is higher or longer if everything is very stable.

faqs.question: Do baby teeth really matter?
faqs.answer: Yes. Healthy baby teeth guide adult teeth into place, support speech, and allow comfortable eating. Protecting them reduces the risk of pain, infection, or early tooth loss.

faqs.question: What if my child is scared?
faqs.answer: Tell us ahead of time and we’ll keep visits short, use tell-show-do, and let them stay in control. We can build up gradually with positive language and plenty of breaks.

sections.title: Gum disease
sections.body:
Gum disease is a common condition that affects the tissues supporting the teeth.

It often develops gradually and may not cause pain in its early stages, which means it can progress unnoticed for some time.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, gum disease is managed with a long-term view, focusing on understanding causes, stabilising the condition, and supporting ongoing oral health.
bullets: Gum disease is a common condition that affects the tissues supporting the teeth.
It often develops gradually and may not cause pain in its early stages, which means it can progress unnoticed for some time.
At St Mary’s House Dental Care, gum disease is managed with a long-term view, focusing on understanding causes, stabilising the condition, and supporting ongoing oral health.

sections.title: Why gum health matters
items: Healthy gums provide essential support for teeth.
When gum disease progresses, it can compromise tooth stability and affect long-term oral health. Managing gum health helps protect existing dental work and reduces the risk of future problems.
The aim is stability rather than perfection.
For many patients, maintaining comfort and preventing further progression is a realistic and successful outcome.

sections.title: What gum disease is
sections.body:
Gum disease occurs when bacteria build up around the teeth and gums, leading to inflammation and damage to the supporting tissues.

In its early form, known as gingivitis, the gums may bleed or appear swollen. If left untreated, it can progress to periodontitis, where bone and supporting structures are affected.

Not everyone progresses at the same rate, and severity varies between individuals.
bullets: Gum disease occurs when bacteria build up around the teeth and gums, leading to inflammation and damage to the supporting tissues.
In its early form, known as gingivitis, the gums may bleed or appear swollen. If left untreated, it can progress to periodontitis, where bone and supporting structures are affected.
Not everyone progresses at the same rate, and severity varies between individuals.

sections.title: Common signs and symptoms
items: Signs of gum disease can include bleeding when brushing, red or swollen gums, persistent bad breath, gum recession, loose teeth, or changes in bite.
Some people experience very few symptoms, which is why regular assessment is important.

sections.title: Assessment and diagnosis
items: Assessment involves examining the gums, measuring gum health around the teeth, reviewing X-rays where appropriate, and considering individual risk factors.
This helps determine the stage of gum disease and the most appropriate management approach.
Findings are discussed clearly so you understand what they mean for you.
sections.strapline: Findings are discussed clearly so you understand what they mean for you.

sections.title: Management and treatment
sections.body:
Treatment for gum disease focuses on reducing inflammation and controlling bacterial build-up.

This may involve professional cleaning, tailored oral hygiene advice, and regular monitoring.

Management is usually ongoing rather than a one-off intervention.

sections.title: Maintenance and review
items: Long-term gum health depends on consistent care and review.
Regular appointments allow us to monitor stability, address changes early, and adjust care as needed.
This ongoing approach helps maintain comfort and function over time.

sections.title: Related care to explore
sections.strapline: Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.

sections.title: Answers to common gum care questions

faqs.question: Does deep cleaning hurt?
faqs.answer: Treatment is planned gently with numbing gels or local anaesthetic where needed. You’ll be guided on what to expect and how to keep things comfortable afterwards.

faqs.question: How long does it take to see improvement?
faqs.answer: Gums often look and feel healthier within weeks, but long-term stability depends on regular maintenance and the risk factors we identify together.

faqs.question: Can gum tissue grow back?
faqs.answer: Inflammation can reduce and pockets can tighten with good care. Recession usually needs protective maintenance rather than regrowth, and we’ll discuss options if grafting or referral is appropriate.

faqs.question: What about implants with gum inflammation?
faqs.answer: Peri-implant tissues can often be stabilised with careful cleaning, airflow-style stain removal, and close reviews. If advanced peri-implantitis is present, we’ll outline referral options calmly.

sections.title: Root canal treatment
sections.body:
Root canal treatment is used when the nerve inside a tooth has become inflamed or infected.

The aim is to remove infection, seal the tooth, and keep it stable long-term — often avoiding the need for extraction.

We’ll assess the tooth carefully, explain what we can see (and what we can’t), and recommend the most predictable option for your situation.
bullets: Relieve pain and settle infection
Preserve the tooth where it’s sensible to do so
Restore strength with the right protection afterwards

sections.title: Common signs you might need root canal treatment
items: Pain that lingers after hot or cold
Throbbing pain or pain that wakes you
Pain on biting or when you release the bite
Swelling, a gum ‘spot’, or a bad taste
A tooth that has darkened after previous trauma
sections.strapline: In some cases, there may be little or no pain, and the problem is identified during examination.

sections.title: How treatment usually works
items: We examine the tooth and take X-rays if needed to confirm the cause
We numb the area thoroughly and isolate the tooth to keep things clean
We remove infected tissue and disinfect the canals
We seal the canals and place a suitable temporary or permanent restoration
We discuss the best long-term protection (often an onlay or crown) depending on the tooth

sections.eyebrow: Why root canal treatment may be needed
sections.title: Why planning and precision matter
sections.body:
Root canal treatment is detail work.

Good outcomes depend on seeing the anatomy clearly, cleaning thoroughly, and sealing the tooth well. Sometimes canals are narrow, curved, or hard to locate — and that’s where careful technique and appropriate imaging help.

We’ll explain what we can see on the day and whether the tooth looks straightforward, complex, or uncertain — before we commit you to a plan.
sections.mediaHint: CBCT mapping, rotary instruments, and apex location

sections.title: Comfort, pacing, and anxiety
items: We take time to get you properly numb — pain control is not rushed
We can work in shorter stages if you find long appointments difficult
We explain each step before we do it and agree a clear ‘stop’ signal
If you’re nervous, tell us — we’ll adapt the pace and the plan

sections.title: Limitations and risks
sections.body:
Root canal treatment is usually very successful, but it isn’t magic.

Sometimes anatomy is complex, infection has been present for a long time, or cracks mean the tooth cannot be predictably saved. Occasionally a tooth needs further treatment later, even after an apparently good initial result.

We’ll talk through the realistic risks for your tooth specifically, and what the alternatives would be.
bullets: Success depends on anatomy, infection level, and tooth structure
Some teeth need follow-up treatment or referral if complexity is high
Cracks or severe breakdown can limit prognosis

sections.title: Aftercare and long-term outlook
sections.body:
Once the nerve is treated, the tooth still needs to be protected.

Back teeth in particular often need an onlay or crown afterwards because they’re more likely to fracture. A well-sealed, well-protected tooth can last many years, but maintenance matters.

We’ll recommend the simplest protection that gives the tooth the best chance of staying stable.
bullets: Follow-up checks are part of good endodontic care
Protecting the tooth afterwards is often the key to longevity
We plan for stability, not short-term patching

faqs.question: What if I’m unsure whether I need root canal treatment?
faqs.answer:
Root canal treatment should not be painful — the tooth is numbed thoroughly and we work carefully.

People often come in expecting the worst because they’re already in pain. In reality, the aim is to remove the source of that pain and make the tooth comfortable again.

If you’re anxious, tell us. We can pace the appointment, take breaks, and keep the plan simple.

sections.title: Talk to us about root canal treatment
sections.body:
If you have toothache, lingering sensitivity, or swelling, it’s worth getting the tooth assessed.

We’ll explain what’s going on, whether the tooth is realistically savable, and what the next step should be — without pressure.

sections.title: Dental extractions
sections.body:
A dental extraction involves the removal of a tooth that cannot be maintained comfortably or predictably over the long term.

Extractions are usually considered only when other options are unlikely to succeed or would not offer a stable long-term outcome.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, the focus is always on preserving teeth where possible and recommending extraction only when it’s genuinely in a patient’s best interest.
bullets: Calm assessments that explain when extraction is the safest route
Minimally invasive techniques to protect bone and gum
Aftercare and future planning for implants, bridges, or dentures

sections.title: When an extraction may be recommended
items: An extraction may be advised if a tooth is severely damaged by decay, infection, fracture, or advanced gum disease.
It may also be considered where a tooth is causing ongoing pain, repeated infection, or is affecting the health of surrounding teeth.
We’ll always explain why removal is being suggested and what alternatives have been considered.
sections.strapline: If you experience rapid swelling, spreading infection, or difficulty swallowing, treat it as urgent and contact us for emergency dentistry advice.

sections.title: Assessment and planning
items: Before recommending an extraction, we carry out a careful assessment.
This includes examining the tooth, reviewing X-rays or scans where appropriate, and considering how removal may affect function, comfort, and future treatment.
Planning helps ensure the procedure is carried out as smoothly and safely as possible.

sections.title: What an extraction involves
sections.body:
Dental extractions are carried out under local anaesthetic.

Once the area is numb, the tooth is removed carefully, with the aim of minimising trauma to surrounding tissues.

The procedure itself is usually straightforward, although complexity can vary depending on the tooth and its position.
sections.mediaHint: CBCT-guided planning and minimally invasive instruments

sections.title: Comfort and what to expect
items: Many patients worry about discomfort during or after an extraction.
The procedure is carried out once the area is numb, and we’ll talk you through what sensations to expect. Some soreness afterwards is normal and usually settles over time.
We’ll provide clear aftercare advice to support healing.

sections.title: Aftercare and healing
sections.body:
After an extraction, it’s important to allow the area to heal properly.

This may involve avoiding certain foods, keeping the area clean, and following specific instructions to reduce the risk of complications.

We’ll explain what’s normal during healing and when to get in touch if concerns arise.
bullets: Discussion of saving versus removing a tooth with restorative or endodontic care
Clear consent for complex roots, impacted teeth, or medical considerations
Alternatives such as monitoring or referral to surgical colleagues when indicated
Planning for provisional solutions while you heal

sections.title: Replacing a missing tooth
sections.body:
If a tooth is removed, options for replacement may be discussed.

These can include leaving the space, using a denture, placing a bridge, or considering a dental implant, depending on the situation.

Any replacement is planned carefully and never rushed.
bullets: Monitoring to confirm bone and gum health before replacement
Advice on protecting the site to maintain bone volume
Discussion of implant planning or bridgework once healing allows
Ongoing reviews to keep surrounding teeth and gums healthy

faqs.question: Questions and reassurance
faqs.answer:
Being told a tooth needs to be removed can feel daunting.

If you’re unsure why an extraction has been suggested or what it means for you, we encourage you to ask. Clear explanations help support confident, informed decisions.

faqs.question: How long is recovery?
faqs.answer: Most people are comfortable after a few days with steady improvement over 1–2 weeks. We give written instructions to support smooth healing.

faqs.question: Can the tooth be replaced?
faqs.answer: Yes. We will discuss timing for implants, bridges, or dentures once the area is stable, and we can provide provisional solutions if needed.

faqs.question: What if the tooth could be saved?
faqs.answer: If a filling, crown, or root canal could provide a predictable result, we’ll explain that option first so you can make an informed choice.

sections.title: Nervous patients
sections.copy:
If you feel anxious about dentistry, you’re not alone — and you don’t need to ‘push through it’ to get help.

We take a calm, practical approach: clear explanations, gentle pacing, and treatment planned in stages when that makes things easier.

Sometimes the best first appointment is simply a conversation and an examination. We’ll agree a plan together — with comfort and control built in from the start.

sections.title: Who this is for
items: People who want clear explanations rather than being rushed
People who prefer to build trust gradually, one step at a time
People who value a predictable, no-surprises approach
sections.strapline: Real anxiety. Real life. A plan that respects both.

sections.title: What people often tell us
items: Worry about pain, gagging, or feeling out of control
Past difficult experiences or dental trauma
Sensitivity to sounds, smells, lights, or sensations
Fear of judgement or embarrassment
Concern about costs, pressure, or unexpected treatment
sections.strapline: These are normal concerns — and we plan around them.

sections.title: What to expect
sections.body:
We’ll start by understanding what makes dentistry difficult for you. That might be a specific fear (needles, numbness, drilling), sensory overload, a past experience, or simply not knowing what’s going to happen.

Depending on your needs, we can:
- go at a slower pace, with breaks
- agree a clear ‘stop’ signal so you stay in control
- explain each step before we do it
- stage care so it feels manageable rather than overwhelming

If sedation is relevant, we can explain when it may be appropriate and what it involves. Not everyone needs it — for many people, pacing and predictability are the biggest difference.
bullets: A calm, non-judgemental conversation first
An examination (and X-rays only if needed)
Clear options and costs explained before treatment
A staged plan that fits your tolerance and goals

items: Start with a discussion and gentle assessment
Stabilise urgent issues first (comfort and safety)

Build familiarity with the team, environment, and steps
sections.strapline: Small steps count. Stability first. Confidence follows.

sections.title: Tooth wear and erosion
sections.copy:
Tooth wear refers to the gradual loss of tooth structure over time.

It’s a common issue and often develops slowly, meaning many people don’t notice it until changes in shape, sensitivity, or appearance become more obvious.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, tooth wear is managed thoughtfully, with an emphasis on understanding why it’s happening before deciding how to treat it.
bullets: Tooth wear refers to the gradual loss of tooth structure over time
It often develops slowly before changes become more obvious
Care focuses on understanding why it’s happening before deciding how to treat it

sections.title: Common causes
items: Factors contributing to tooth wear can include acidic foods or drinks, reflux, dry mouth, clenching or grinding, bite relationships, and lifestyle habits
Often, tooth wear results from a combination of influences rather than a single cause

sections.title: Different types of tooth wear
items: Tooth wear can occur for different reasons
Erosion is caused by acids softening the tooth surface
Attrition is wear from tooth-to-tooth contact, often linked to clenching or grinding
Abrasion involves mechanical wear, such as from brushing habits
More than one type of wear is often present at the same time

sections.label: Assessment
sections.title: Why careful assessment matters
sections.copy:
Understanding the cause and pattern of wear helps guide appropriate management.

Assessment may include examining how teeth meet, looking for signs of muscle activity, reviewing diet and habits, and checking for changes over time.

Not all wear requires immediate treatment, but monitoring is important.
sections.mediaHint: Photos, scans, and bite map overlay

sections.title: Management and prevention
items: Management often begins with prevention
This may include monitoring, protective appliances such as night guards, dietary advice, and targeted dental treatment where appropriate.
Often, more than one measure is used together, depending on how wear is progressing
The aim is to slow or stop progression before considering restorative treatment

sections.title: When treatment may be needed
sections.copy:
If tooth wear is advanced or causing functional or comfort issues, treatment may be discussed.

Options can range from simple protective measures to restorative approaches designed to rebuild worn surfaces.

Any proposed treatment is planned carefully and staged where possible.
bullets: Treatment is considered when wear affects comfort or function
Options range from protective measures to restorations
Plans are staged and tailored to the individual

sections.label: Long-term outlook
sections.title: Long-term outlook
sections.copy:
Tooth wear is usually a long-term consideration rather than a quick fix.

Ongoing review helps ensure that teeth remain comfortable and functional, and that any intervention remains appropriate as circumstances change.

sections.strapline: Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.

faqs.question: What if I’m unsure about what tooth wear means for me?
faqs.answer:
Learning that your teeth are wearing can be concerning.

If you’re unsure what it means for you, we encourage you to ask. Understanding the situation clearly helps avoid unnecessary treatment and supports sensible long-term decisions.

We’ll talk through your goals, skin quality, and what’s realistic, then recommend a plan only if it’s appropriate and safe for you.

sections.title: Polynucleotides consultation

Polynucleotides are used to support skin quality over time — often focusing on texture, hydration, and a healthier-looking finish rather than dramatic ‘instant’ change.

We’ll talk through your goals, assess what’s realistic, and recommend a plan only if it’s appropriate, subtle, and safe.

sections.strapline:
Mouthguards and retainers can protect teeth during sport, help maintain orthodontic results, and reduce wear from clenching in the right situations.

We’ll assess your bite and risks, then recommend the simplest option that genuinely helps — without over-treating.
